questions.question: A primary advantage of partnership taxation compared to C corporation taxation is:

options.B: Single level of taxation on business income
options.C: Lower tax rates on business income

questions.explanation: Partnerships provide pass-through taxation where income is taxed only at the partner level, avoiding double taxation. Limited liability depends on the entity type (LP, LLP, LLC), not tax classification. Tax rates depend on partner status. Partnership returns can be complex due to allocation requirements.
questions.tip: Partnership = pass-through (no entity tax). C corp = double tax potential (entity + shareholder).

questions.question: Property contributions to a partnership are generally:

options.B: Tax-free regardless of percentage received
options.C: Tax-free if the partner receives an 80% interest

questions.explanation: Under Section 721, property contributions to a partnership are generally tax-free without any control requirement (unlike Section 351 for corporations which requires 80% control). Partners take carryover basis in their interest. Exceptions exist for contributions of services, certain disguised sales, and debt in excess of basis.
questions.tip: Partnership contributions = no control test (unlike Section 351). Generally tax-free regardless of % received.

questions.question: A partner's outside basis includes the partner's share of partnership:

options.B: Recourse and nonrecourse liabilities
options.C: Expenses only

questions.explanation: A partner's outside basis includes capital contributions, share of income, and share of partnership liabilities (both recourse and nonrecourse under Section 752). This differs from S corporations where shareholders generally do not include their share of entity debt in basis.
questions.tip: Partnership basis includes share of ALL partnership debt. S corp basis includes only direct shareholder loans.

questions.question: Partnership allocations of income and loss:

options.A: Must be made in proportion to capital contributions
options.B: Must be made equally among partners
options.C: Can be specially allocated if they have substantial economic effect
options.D: Must be made in proportion to ownership percentages

questions.explanation: Partnerships have flexibility to make special allocations (different from ownership percentages) if the allocations have substantial economic effect under Section 704(b). This means allocations must affect the partners' economic interests (through capital accounts and liquidation rights), not just tax benefits.
questions.tip: Special allocations allowed if substantial economic effect. Must affect real economics, not just taxes.

questions.question: A current (nonliquidating) distribution of cash from a partnership to a partner is generally:

options.B: Tax-free to the extent of the partner's basis
options.C: Taxable as a capital gain

questions.explanation: Current cash distributions are tax-free to the extent of the partner's outside basis. Cash distributed in excess of basis is treated as gain from the sale of the partnership interest (typically capital gain). This allows partners to withdraw previously-taxed income without additional tax.
questions.tip: Partnership cash distribution: tax-free up to basis, capital gain on excess.

questions.question: A general partner's distributive share of ordinary partnership income is generally:

options.B: Subject to self-employment tax
options.C: Subject to FICA tax withholding

questions.explanation: A general partner's distributive share of ordinary trade or business income is subject to self-employment tax. Limited partners are generally exempt from SE tax on their distributive share (except for guaranteed payments for services). This is a key difference from S corporation treatment.
questions.tip: General partners = SE tax on ordinary income. Limited partners = generally exempt (except guaranteed payments).

questions.question: Guaranteed payments to a partner for services are:

options.A: Deductible by the partnership and treated as self-employment income to the partner
options.B: Not deductible by the partnership but treated as wages to the partner
options.C: Deductible by the partnership and treated as capital gain to the partner
options.D: Added to the partner's capital account

questions.explanation: Guaranteed payments for services are deductible by the partnership (reducing ordinary income to other partners) and reported as ordinary/self-employment income to the receiving partner. They are determined without regard to partnership income. The partner is not treated as an employee, so no withholding applies.
questions.tip: Guaranteed payments: deductible by partnership, SE income to partner. No employment tax withholding - partner pays SE tax.

questions.question: Nonrecourse liabilities of a partnership are generally allocated among partners based on:

options.B: Their share of partnership minimum gain
options.C: Economic risk of loss

questions.explanation: Nonrecourse liabilities are allocated in three tiers: (1) first to partners with minimum gain, (2) then to partners per Section 704(c) built-in gain allocation, (3) finally to all partners based on profit-sharing ratios. Since no partner bears economic risk for nonrecourse debt, it's shared based on minimum gain and profits.
questions.tip: Nonrecourse debt allocation: minimum gain first, 704(c) second, then profit ratios. No economic risk = shared allocation.

questions.question: A Section 754 election benefits an incoming partner who pays more than book value for a partnership interest because it:

options.A: Allows the new partner to receive a larger share of profits
options.B: Provides a stepped-up basis in partnership assets for the new partner
options.C: Reduces the selling partner's gain
options.D: Eliminates the requirement to file Form 1065

questions.explanation: A Section 754 election allows the partnership to adjust the basis of its assets with respect to a transferee partner (Section 743(b) adjustment). This prevents the new partner from being taxed on gain already paid for in the purchase price. Without 754, the new partner would share in gain when appreciated assets are sold.
questions.tip: Section 754 protects new partners from double tax on gain already paid for. Creates inside basis adjustment.

questions.question: A property contribution followed by a distribution to the contributing partner may be recharacterized as a sale if:

options.A: The distribution occurs more than 7 years after contribution
options.B: The distribution occurs within 2 years and is not subject to entrepreneurial risk
options.C: The partner receives a 50% or greater interest
options.D: The property was held less than one year

questions.explanation: Under the disguised sale rules (Section 707(a)(2)(B)), a contribution and related distribution within 2 years may be recharacterized as a sale, requiring gain recognition. A presumption of disguised sale applies if the distribution occurs within 2 years and the distribution is not subject to the entrepreneurial risks of partnership operations.
questions.tip: Disguised sale: contribution + distribution within 2 years presumed a sale. After 2 years, presumed not a sale.

questions.question: When a partner contributes property with built-in gain, Section 704(c) requires:

options.A: Immediate recognition of the built-in gain
options.B: Allocation of the pre-contribution gain to the contributing partner when the property is sold
options.C: Equal sharing of all gains among partners
options.D: Reduction of the contributing partner's capital account

questions.explanation: Section 704(c) prevents shifting of pre-contribution gains or losses to other partners. When property with built-in gain or loss is contributed and later sold, the pre-contribution gain or loss must be allocated to the contributing partner. Several methods (traditional, curative, remedial) accomplish this.
questions.tip: 704(c) = contributing partner keeps their built-in gain/loss. Prevents shifting tax attributes to other partners.

questions.question: Recourse liabilities of a partnership are allocated to partners who bear:

options.B: The economic risk of loss for the liability
options.C: The largest profit-sharing percentage

questions.explanation: Recourse liabilities are allocated to partners who bear the economic risk of loss, determined by a constructive liquidation test. A partner bears economic risk of loss if they would be obligated to make payment without right of reimbursement if the partnership constructively liquidated.
questions.tip: Recourse debt → to partner with economic risk of loss (often general partners, guarantors).

questions.question: In a current distribution, a partner's basis in distributed property is generally:

options.A: Fair market value of the property
options.B: The partnership's basis, limited to the partner's outside basis
options.C: The partnership's basis plus gain recognized

questions.explanation: In a current distribution, the partner takes carryover basis in distributed property (partnership's basis), but this is limited to the partner's remaining outside basis after any cash distributed. This prevents creating loss through property distributions while preserving deferred gain.
questions.tip: Property distribution basis = carryover (partnership's basis), capped at partner's remaining outside basis.

questions.question: When a partner sells their partnership interest, ordinary income may result from the sale due to:

options.B: Section 751(a) - unrealized receivables and inventory items
options.C: Section 704(c) built-in gain

questions.explanation: Section 751(a) (hot assets) treats gain attributable to unrealized receivables (including recapture) and inventory items as ordinary income rather than capital gain. This prevents converting ordinary income to capital gain through partnership interest sales.
questions.tip: Hot assets = ordinary income on partnership sale. Includes receivables, inventory, recapture items.

questions.question: For a special allocation to have economic effect, the partnership agreement must provide for:

options.B: Maintenance of capital accounts and liquidation according to capital account balances
options.C: Equal profit and loss sharing
options.D: Unanimous partner consent for each allocation

questions.explanation: Economic effect requires: (1) capital accounts maintained under Section 704(b), (2) liquidating distributions made in accordance with positive capital accounts, and (3) partners with deficit balances must restore them (or have a qualified income offset). These rules ensure allocations affect real economics.
questions.tip: Economic effect = capital account maintenance + liquidation per capital accounts + deficit restoration (or QIO).

questions.question: The 'mixing bowl' rules under Sections 704(c)(1)(B) and 737 prevent:

options.B: Tax-free exchange of contributed property through the partnership
options.C: Partners from receiving guaranteed payments

questions.explanation: Mixing bowl rules prevent using partnerships to exchange property tax-free. Section 704(c)(1)(B) triggers gain if contributed property is distributed to another partner within 7 years. Section 737 triggers gain if a contributing partner receives other property within 7 years while built-in gain remains.
questions.tip: Mixing bowl = anti-abuse for property exchanges via partnership. 7-year window for contributed property.

questions.question: A partnership must generally use the tax year of:

options.B: Its majority interest partners, then principal partners, then least aggregate deferral
options.C: Any year selected by the partners
options.D: The calendar year in all cases

questions.explanation: Partnerships must use the required taxable year rules: (1) the year of majority interest partners (>50% profits and capital), (2) if no majority, the year of all principal partners (≥5% interest), (3) if principal partners differ, the year resulting in least aggregate deferral of income.
questions.tip: Partnership year: majority interest → principal partners → least aggregate deferral. Prevents income deferral.

questions.question: Section 736(a) payments to a retiring partner are treated as:

options.B: Distributive share or guaranteed payment (ordinary income)
options.C: Return of capital

questions.explanation: Section 736(a) payments (for unstated goodwill in service partnerships and payments for future services) are treated as distributive share of partnership income or guaranteed payments - both ordinary income to the recipient. These payments are deductible by the partnership.
questions.tip: 736(a) = ordinary income (distributive share or guaranteed payment). 736(b) = capital/Section 751 treatment.

questions.question: If a partnership assumes liabilities exceeding a contributing partner's basis in contributed property:

options.B: The excess is treated as gain from the sale of a partnership interest
options.C: The partnership's basis in the property is increased
options.D: The partner's capital account becomes negative

questions.explanation: Under Section 752, when a partnership assumes liabilities, the contributing partner is treated as receiving a distribution equal to the liability relief. If this deemed distribution exceeds the partner's basis, the excess is gain from sale of the partnership interest.
questions.tip: Liability assumption = deemed distribution to contributor. If > basis, gain recognized.

questions.question: For a family member to be recognized as a partner for tax purposes when capital is a material income-producing factor:

options.A: The family member must perform substantial services
options.B: The family member must own capital through gift or purchase
options.C: The family member must be over age 18
options.D: The donor must retain a controlling interest

questions.explanation: Under Section 704(e), a person who acquires a capital interest in a partnership where capital is material will be recognized as a partner if they actually own the interest (by gift or purchase). Donee partners must receive reasonable compensation for services before profits are allocated, and the donor's share can't be reduced below reasonable compensation.
questions.tip: Family partnership: donee recognized if capital is material income-producing factor. Reasonable allocation required.

questions.question: Distributions of marketable securities from a partnership are treated as:

options.B: Cash distributions, potentially triggering gain
options.C: Capital contributions by other partners

questions.explanation: Under Section 731(c), marketable securities distributed by a partnership are generally treated as money (cash) rather than property. This can trigger gain recognition if the value exceeds the partner's basis. Exceptions apply for securities contributed by the distributee partner and certain investment partnerships.
questions.tip: Marketable securities = treated as cash for distribution purposes. Can trigger gain like cash distribution.

questions.question: A Section 743(b) adjustment is mandatory (without election) when:

options.B: The partnership has a substantial built-in loss (exceeding $250,000)
options.C: The partnership distributes appreciated property
options.D: A partner receives a guaranteed payment

questions.explanation: A Section 743(b) adjustment is mandatory when a partnership interest is transferred and the partnership has a substantial built-in loss (inside basis exceeds FMV by more than $250,000). Similarly, Section 734(b) adjustment is mandatory when a substantial basis reduction occurs. This prevents loss trafficking.
questions.tip: Mandatory 754: >$250K built-in loss on transfer. Prevents trafficking in partnership losses.

questions.question: Under current law, a partnership continues for tax purposes unless:

options.A: 50% or more of partnership interests are transferred within 12 months
options.B: All partnership operations cease completely
options.C: The partnership is merged into another partnership

questions.explanation: After TCJA repealed technical terminations, a partnership now continues for tax purposes until operations cease completely or a partnership merger/division occurs. The old rule triggering termination on 50%+ interest transfer in 12 months was eliminated for tax years after December 31, 2017.
questions.tip: Technical terminations repealed by TCJA. Partnership continues until operations cease or merger/division.

questions.question: Section 751(b) applies when a distribution causes a partner to:

options.A: Receive less than their profit share
options.B: Exchange an interest in hot assets for an interest in cold assets or vice versa
options.C: Receive property with a basis less than fair market value

questions.explanation: Section 751(b) treats a distribution as a taxable exchange to the extent a partner receives more or less than their proportionate share of Section 751 property (hot assets - unrealized receivables and inventory) in exchange for other property. This prevents converting ordinary income to capital gain through distributions.
questions.tip: 751(b) = disproportionate distributions of hot assets. Deemed exchange triggers ordinary income.

questions.question: An allocation lacks substantiality if:

options.A: It results in a partner's share of income equaling their loss share
options.B: The after-tax consequences differ from what they would be without the allocation
options.C: The allocation reduces overall taxes without substantially affecting partners' capital accounts
options.D: The allocation is made at year-end

questions.explanation: Substantiality requires that there be a reasonable possibility the allocation will substantially affect dollar amounts received by partners independent of tax consequences. 'Shifting' allocations (that net out over time) and 'transitory' allocations (that offset in the same year) fail the substantiality test.
questions.tip: Substantiality = allocation must affect real economics, not just taxes. Shifting and transitory allocations fail.

questions.question: Tiered partnership structures may provide tax planning benefits by:

options.A: Eliminating the need for Section 754 elections
options.B: Allowing different allocation schemes at different partnership levels
options.C: Converting ordinary income to capital gain

questions.explanation: Tiered structures allow different allocation arrangements at each level. Upper-tier partnerships can aggregate multiple investments, facilitate tax-efficient carried interest structures, and provide flexibility for different investor classes. However, anti-abuse rules and look-through rules apply to prevent manipulation.
questions.tip: Tiered partnerships = flexibility in allocation structures. Watch for look-through and anti-abuse rules.

questions.question: A profits interest granted to a service partner is generally:

options.A: Taxable at fair market value upon receipt
options.B: Not taxable upon receipt if Rev. Proc. 93-27 safe harbor requirements are met
options.C: Treated as a guaranteed payment
options.D: Subject to immediate capital gains tax

questions.explanation: Under Rev. Proc. 93-27 and 2001-43, a profits interest (right to future profits, not existing capital) is generally not taxable upon receipt if: (1) the interest is not related to a substantially certain stream of income, (2) the partner doesn't dispose of it within 2 years, and (3) it's not a publicly traded interest.
questions.tip: Profits interest = generally tax-free at grant under safe harbor. Capital interest = taxable at FMV on receipt.

questions.question: Under Section 1061, gain from an applicable partnership interest (carried interest) receives long-term capital gain treatment only if the holding period exceeds:

options.B: Two years
options.C: Three years

questions.explanation: Section 1061 requires a 3-year holding period (instead of 1 year) for long-term capital gain treatment on gains from applicable partnership interests (carried interests). Gains on assets held 1-3 years are recharacterized as short-term capital gain. This affects fund managers and other service providers receiving profits interests.
questions.tip: Carried interest = 3-year hold for LTCG treatment (vs. normal 1-year). Section 1061.

questions.question: When a partner receives a current distribution, outside basis is reduced first by:

options.A: The fair market value of property distributed
options.B: The amount of any cash distributed
options.C: The partnership's basis in distributed property
options.D: The partner's share of income for the year

questions.explanation: In a current distribution, basis is reduced first by cash received (dollar for dollar, potentially triggering gain if exceeding basis), then by the partnership's basis in distributed property (limited to remaining basis). Property basis reduction comes after cash because cash can trigger gain while property generally cannot in current distributions.
questions.tip: Distribution order: reduce basis by cash first (can trigger gain), then property basis (limited to remaining basis).

questions.question: A Section 734(b) basis adjustment is made to partnership assets when:

options.B: A partner sells their interest
options.C: A distribution results in gain or basis adjustment to the distributee partner

questions.explanation: Section 734(b) adjustments apply when a distribution occurs and the partnership has a Section 754 election in effect (or mandatory adjustment applies). The partnership adjusts its asset basis by: gain recognized by distributee, or the difference between distributed property's carryover basis and inside basis.
questions.tip: 734(b) = distribution adjustments. 743(b) = transfer adjustments. Both require 754 election (or mandatory trigger).

questions.question: A debt-financed distribution to a contributing partner may be recharacterized as a disguised sale if:

options.A: The debt exceeds the property's fair market value
options.B: The partnership borrows specifically to fund the distribution and the partner contributed property within 2 years
options.C: The partner contributes additional capital
options.D: The debt is recourse to all partners

questions.explanation: When a partnership borrows funds and distributes them to a contributing partner, and these transactions are related (within 2 years), the IRS may treat the contribution and distribution as a disguised sale. The regulations provide detailed rules for analyzing whether the debt-financed distribution is disguised sale proceeds.
questions.tip: Debt-financed distribution + contribution within 2 years = potential disguised sale. Analyze the facts carefully.

questions.question: The partnership anti-abuse rule under Reg. 1.701-2 allows the IRS to:

options.A: Automatically convert partnerships to C corporations
options.B: Recast transactions to achieve tax results consistent with the intent of subchapter K
options.C: Impose a 20% penalty on all partnership allocations

questions.explanation: The anti-abuse rule allows the IRS to recast partnership transactions that comply technically with subchapter K but produce tax results inconsistent with the intent of subchapter K. The IRS can treat the partnership as an aggregate, adjust allocations, or disregard transactions entirely.
questions.tip: Anti-abuse rule: IRS can recast transactions that technically comply but abuse subchapter K intent.

questions.question: When two partnerships merge, the resulting partnership is treated as a continuation of:

options.A: The partnership with the larger number of partners
options.B: The partnership whose partners own more than 50% of the resulting partnership's capital and profits
options.C: Both partnerships equally
options.D: Neither partnership (a new partnership is formed)

questions.explanation: In a partnership merger, the resulting partnership is a continuation of the partnership whose partners own more than 50% of capital and profits in the merged entity. The other partnership is terminated, and its partners are deemed to contribute assets to the continuing partnership in exchange for interests.
questions.tip: Partnership merger: >50% capital/profits determines which continues. Other partnership terminates.

questions.question: A publicly traded partnership (PTP) is generally taxed as a corporation unless:

options.B: 90% or more of its gross income is qualifying income (passive-type income)
options.C: It elects partnership tax treatment

questions.explanation: Publicly traded partnerships are taxed as corporations unless 90% or more of their gross income is qualifying income: interest, dividends, real property rents, gain from real property sales, and income from natural resource activities. MLPs in the oil, gas, and real estate sectors often meet this exception.
questions.tip: PTP = taxed as C corp unless 90%+ qualifying income (passive/resource income). Most MLPs qualify.

questions.question: Under Section 705, a partner's outside basis is decreased by:

options.B: The partner's distributive share of tax-exempt income
options.C: The partner's distributive share of partnership losses and nondeductible expenditures

questions.explanation: Section 705 decreases outside basis for: distributions, the partner's share of partnership losses and deductions, and the partner's share of nondeductible expenditures (like non-allowed meals deduction, penalties) that are not capital items. Tax-exempt income increases basis; guaranteed payments don't directly affect basis.
questions.tip: Basis decreases: distributions, losses, nondeductible non-capital items. Increases: income (including tax-exempt), contributions.
